docs.title: Welcome to Techexcel BackOffice Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the enhanced documentation for the Lucee CFML Engine. This documentation aims to provide comprehensive information about using and configuring Lucee for your applications.

docs.title: Web Administrator Interface
docs.text:
Quick Access

Access the Lucee Web Administrator at: http://your-domain:8888/lucee/admin/web.cfm

docs.title: Configuration Files
Performance Settings
docs.text: Setting Default Recommended Description Scope Cascading strict strict Defines variable scope resolution Template Cache true true Caches compiled templates Query Cache false true Caches database queries

docs.text:
graph TD
    A[JVM Memory] --> B[Heap Memory]
    A --> C[Non-Heap Memory]
    B --> D[Young Generation]
    B --> E[Old Generation]
    C --> F[Metaspace]

docs.title: Memory Settings
docs.text:
# JVM Settings
-Xms512m      # Initial Heap Size
-Xmx2048m     # Maximum Heap Size
-XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=256m

docs.title: Datasource Setup
docs.text:
-- Example Database Configuration
CREATE DATABASE myapp;
CREATE USER myapp_user WITH PASSWORD 'secure_password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON DATABASE myapp TO myapp_user;

docs.title: Connection Settings
docs.text:
datasource:
  name: MyAppDS
  class: org.postgresql.Driver
  url: jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/myapp
  username: myapp_user

docs.title: Mail Server Configuration
docs.text:
mail.server=smtp.example.com
mail.port=587
mail.username=user@example.com
mail.password=******
mail.tls=true

docs.title: Log Levels
docs.text:
• ERROR - Critical issues
  • WARN - Warning messages
  • INFO - Information messages
  • DEBUG - Debug information

docs.title: Debug Settings
docs.text:
<cfset application.debugEnabled = true>
<cfset application.debugIPRange = "192.168.1.*">

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Purpose Example LUCEE_HOME Installation directory /opt/lucee JAVA_HOME Java installation /usr/lib/jvm/java-11 PATH System path ${LUCEE_HOME}/bin

# Extension Installation Command
box install commandbox-cfconfig

docs.text:

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text: Lucee System Architecture Overview

docs.title: Hardware Requirements
docs.text: Component Minimum Recommended CPU 2 cores 4+ cores RAM 2 GB 4+ GB Disk Space 500 MB 1+ GB Network 1 Mbps 10+ Mbps

docs.title: Software Prerequisites
docs.text:
WindowsLinuxmacOS
  • Windows 10/11 or Server 2019/2022
  • Java 8 or higher
  • Visual C++ Redistributable
  • Ubuntu 20.04/22.04 or RHEL 8/9
  • OpenJDK 8 or higher
  • Required packages: 
    sudo apt install fontconfig libfreetype6
  • macOS 11 (Big Sur) or higher
  • Java 8 or higher
  • Xcode Command Line Tools

docs.title: Step 1: Pre-Installation Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Download the correct installer for your OS
  • [ ] Verify system requirements
  • [ ] Backup existing configuration (if upgrading)
  • [ ] Close conflicting applications

docs.title: Step 2: Installation Process
docs.text:
Windows InstallationLinux InstallationmacOS Installation
  1. Run the installer as Administrator
  2. Choose installation directory
  3. Configure ports: 
    HTTP Port: 8888
HTTPS Port: 8443
AJP Port: 8009
  4. Set administrator password
  5. Choose service options
  1. Extract the archive: 
    tar xzf lucee-linux-x64.tar.gz
  2. Run the installation script: 
    sudo ./install.sh
  3. Configure the service: 
    sudo systemctl enable lucee
sudo systemctl start lucee
  1. Open the package installer
  2. Follow the installation wizard
  3. Configure through System Preferences
  4. Start the service: 
    sudo launchctl load /Library/LaunchDaemons/lucee.plist

docs.title: Step 3: Post-Installation
docs.text:
Verification Steps

  1. Open web browser
  2. Visit http://localhost:8888
  3. Log in to admin console
  4. Run health check

Security Steps

  1. Change default passwords
  2. Configure firewall rules
  3. Set up SSL certificates
  4. Review security settings

docs.title: Basic Configuration
docs.text: Setting Default Recommended Memory (Xmx) 512MB 2GB Temp Directory /tmp /var/lucee/temp Session Timeout 30min 60min

docs.text:
Download our configuration templates:

  • Basic Configuration Template
  • Production Configuration Template
  • High-Performance Configuration

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Port Conflicts

If ports are already in use: 1. Check running services 2. Choose alternative ports 3. Update configuration

Memory Issues

If experiencing memory problems: 1. Adjust JVM settings 2. Monitor memory usage 3. Configure garbage collection

Permission Errors

For permission-related issues: 1. Verify user permissions 2. Check file ownership 3. Set correct SELinux context

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to Lucee! This guide will help you get started with Lucee CFML Engine quickly and efficiently.

Before You Begin

Make sure you have Java 8 or higher installed on your system.

docs.title: 1. Download Lucee
docs.text:
Download the latest version of Lucee from the official website:

:octicons-download-16: Download Lucee

docs.title: 2. System Requirements
docs.text:
Your system needs:

  • Java 8+
  • 2GB RAM minimum
  • 500MB disk space

docs.title: 3. Installation Process
docs.text:
WindowsLinux
  1. Run the installer
  2. Choose installation directory
  3. Configure ports
  4. Start Lucee
  1. Extract the archive
  2. Run setup script
  3. Update permissions
  4. Start service

docs.title: First Application
docs.text:
Create your first Lucee application:

hello.cfm
<cfoutput>
    <h1 style="color: ##FF0000;">Hello, Lucee!</h1>
    <p>Current time: #now()#</p>
</cfoutput>

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
Here are some important concepts to remember:

  1. Tags - Basic building blocks
  2. Functions - Built-in capabilities
  3. Expressions - Dynamic content

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
Different ways to configure Lucee:

Method Scope Difficulty Web Admin Server-wide Easy Config Files Application Medium Code-based Component Advanced

docs.title: Quick Tips
docs.text:
Best Practices

  • Use CFScript for modern syntax
  • Keep security in mind
  • Practice error handling

Common Pitfalls

Be careful with:

  1. Case sensitivity in Linux
  2. Memory allocation
  3. Cache settings

docs.title: Basic Script
Advanced Features
docs.text:
Here's how to use some advanced features:

  • :material-clock-fast: Quick Cache

    <cfset cache.put("key", "value")>

  • :material-database: Database

    <cfquery name="users">
    SELECT * FROM users
</cfquery>

docs.title: Minimum Specifications
docs.text:
• CPU: Dual-core processor, 2.0 GHz
  • RAM: 2 GB
  • Disk Space: 500 MB
  • Network: 100 Mbps

docs.title: Recommended for Production
docs.text:
• CPU: Quad-core processor, 3.0+ GHz
  • RAM: 8 GB
  • Disk Space: 2 GB
  • Network: 1 Gbps

docs.title: Lucee Functions Reference
docs.text: This document provides a comprehensive reference for built-in functions available in Lucee.

docs.title: String Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example len() Returns the length of a string len("Hello") // Returns 5 left() Returns leftmost characters left("Hello", 2) // Returns "He" right() Returns rightmost characters right("Hello", 2) // Returns "lo" mid() Returns a substring mid("Hello", 2, 2) // Returns "el" trim() Removes leading/trailing spaces trim(" Hello ") // Returns "Hello" lTrim() Removes leading spaces lTrim(" Hello ") // Returns "Hello " rTrim() Removes trailing spaces rTrim(" Hello ") // Returns " Hello" uCase() Converts to uppercase uCase("Hello") // Returns "HELLO" lCase() Converts to lowercase lCase("Hello") // Returns "hello"

docs.title: Numeric Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example abs() Returns absolute value abs(-5) // Returns 5 round() Rounds a number round(3.7) // Returns 4 ceiling() Rounds up to nearest integer ceiling(3.1) // Returns 4 floor() Rounds down to nearest integer floor(3.7) // Returns 3 max() Returns larger of two numbers max(5, 10) // Returns 10 min() Returns smaller of two numbers min(5, 10) // Returns 5 rand() Generates random number rand() // Returns random number

docs.title: Array Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example arrayLen() Returns array length arrayLen([1,2,3]) // Returns 3 arrayAppend() Adds element to array arrayAppend(arr, element) arraySort() Sorts array elements arraySort(arr, "textnocase") arrayToList() Converts array to list arrayToList([1,2,3]) // Returns "1,2,3" arrayFind() Finds element in array arrayFind(arr, element)

docs.title: Structure Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example structNew() Creates new structure structNew() structCount() Returns count of keys structCount(struct) structDelete() Deletes key from structure structDelete(struct, key) structFind() Finds value in structure structFind(struct, key) structKeyExists() Checks if key exists structKeyExists(struct, key)

docs.title: Date/Time Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example now() Returns current date/time now() dateFormat() Formats date dateFormat(now(), "yyyy-mm-dd") timeFormat() Formats time timeFormat(now(), "HH:mm:ss") dateAdd() Adds interval to date dateAdd("d", 7, now()) dateDiff() Calculates difference between dates dateDiff("d", date1, date2)

docs.title: Type Conversion Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example toString() Converts to string toString(123) toNumeric() Converts to number toNumeric("123") toBinary() Converts to binary toBinary(string) toBase64() Converts to base64 toBase64(string) serialize() Serializes complex objects serialize(object) deserialize() Deserializes string data deserialize(string)

docs.title: Query Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example queryNew() Creates new query queryNew("col1,col2") queryAddRow() Adds row to query queryAddRow(query) querySetCell() Sets cell value querySetCell(query, col, value) queryExecute() Executes SQL query queryExecute(sql, params)

docs.title: File System Functions
docs.text: Function Description Example fileExists() Checks if file exists fileExists(path) fileRead() Reads file content fileRead(path) fileWrite() Writes to file fileWrite(path, content) directoryExists() Checks if directory exists directoryExists(path) directoryCreate() Creates directory directoryCreate(path)

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always check function return types in documentation
  2. Use appropriate error handling with functions that may fail
  3. Consider performance implications with large datasets
  4. Use built-in functions instead of custom implementations when available
  5. Check function compatibility across Lucee versions

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Function names are case-insensitive
  • Many functions have optional parameters
  • Some functions have aliases or alternative names
  • Check the official Lucee documentation for complete parameter lists and usage examples

docs.title: Operators in Lucee
docs.text: This document provides a comprehensive reference for operators available in Lucee.

docs.title: Arithmetic Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example + Addition a + b - Subtraction a - b * Multiplication a * b / Division a / b % Modulus a % b ^ Exponentiation a ^ b ++ Increment a++ -- Decrement a--

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example == Equal a == b === Identical a === b != Not Equal a != b !== Not Identical a !== b > Greater Than a > b >= Greater Than or Equal a >= b < Less Than a < b <= Less Than or Equal a <= b

docs.title: Logical Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example && Logical AND a && b || Logical OR a \|\| b ! Logical NOT !a AND Logical AND (alternative) a AND b OR Logical OR (alternative) a OR b NOT Logical NOT (alternative) NOT a

docs.title: String Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example & String concatenation "Hello" & "World" &= Concatenation assignment str &= "append"

docs.title: Assignment Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example = Simple assignment a = b += Addition assignment a += b -= Subtraction assignment a -= b *= Multiplication assignment a *= b /= Division assignment a /= b %= Modulus assignment a %= b

docs.title: Decision Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example ?: Ternary operator condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse ?? Null coalescing value ?? defaultValue ?: Elvis operator value ?: defaultValue

docs.title: Array and Struct Operators
docs.text: Operator Description Example [] Array/Struct access array[1] or struct["key"] . Member access struct.key

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Operator precedence follows standard programming conventions
  • String comparison is case-insensitive by default
  • The === and !== operators check both value and type
  • The Elvis operator (?:) is a shorthand for null coalescing

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use parentheses to make operator precedence explicit in complex expressions
  2. Prefer === over == when type checking is important
  3. Use meaningful variable names in expressions
  4. Consider using alternative logical operators (AND, OR, NOT) for better readability in complex conditions
